messageBody:
>So said Vladimir Bossicard on 4/7/2003 --------------------
<snip />
>> Maybe I change my opinion. But I am not so blind to overlook all the
>> problems concerning JUnit/TDD.
>
>I don't say (and I think nobody says) that JUnit is perfect (why do
>you think I'm managing JUnit-addons?) but it gives you enough freedom
>to write and test pretty much whatever you want. But of course you
>have to invest some time understanding the framework.

Kent once told me about his vision of JUnit. He described a sign that JUnit was "doing its job": if each person that uses JUnit says, "I needed to add just one or two little things and JUnit was perfect for me," then JUnit has done its job. Kent wanted to build the greatest possible intersection of all people's needs; but remember that the more sets you intersect with, the smaller the intersection...

>Since I haven't used JTest (well, $3500...) I can't really say if
>JTest would be more useful *for me* than JUnit + my addons. But I
>will first learn DbC before learning a new test runner (JTest).

That is a recommended course of action.
